title: (i)DiversiNews a stream-based, on-line service for diversified news

author: Jan Berčič, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute
Mitja Trampuš, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: So I'll be presenting.

The Verge News, which is a piece of software we developed an application for browsing online news while browsing it slightly differently than you would on Google News or any of the related applications.
It allows you to browse in a diversified way, whatever that means, and I'll get to that in a moment.
This was developed by myself.
Flower fart.
Young batch, DeLuca Showstopper and today's timer at our Department.
Now, as I said, the plan is first we'll look at what diversified news browsing is and why we think it's a good idea.
Then we have a short demo given by an and in the end we're going to technical details about the whole.
Software package.
Oh for starters, let's imagine relatively common news browsing situation.
The situation we all encounter daily, or at least weekly.

Some news professionals will encounter it several times a day, which is something happens an event, the story and you want to know more about it for some of the stories, we just want to know, you know the glance, the overview.
But there's things we really care about, like a big event happens next to my house or I'm political investigator and a big bombing attack happens somewhere.
Or I'm a sportscaster in the big.
Match is happening somewhere, so these are the situations where I want to know more, and in this situation what I would do.
Normally I would go to.
Service like Google.

OK, will do it like this.
OK, no problem with the projector, but this is screenshots of Google which I was planning to show in real time and we go to Google and we would get stories like this.
For a story, I can click the title and I would get a single article, a single person's view on that.
Event.
Which probably covers all of the key aspects, but doesn't cover all of all of the details.
It just cannot.
But if I want to know more, I can click this link here.
There's another link here.
It's four more links, probably an.
In fact each of these.
Pictures here is a link to one more article, so I have 510 maybe 15 links on this front page, but very quickly this gets first unwieldy so it's really hard to navigate these 15 similar random links.
These pictures don't tell me anything that's the problem.
Number one and problem #2 is.
It's not just me that's doing this.
Every news professional, so everybody would go to Google News related service.

Those view the top maybe 10 articles and then they would write their own report so all the reports you get in the slowly accumulating news is just the same data being repeated over and over, whereas the fringe facts or maybe views on the matter get kind of pushed to the.
For the background, and are much harder to discover.
So the idea now this is what you would get on Google News.
Then if you try really hard, there's a path of maybe 56 clicks where you can get a whole list of all the articles relating to a story.
And for popular stories you would get maybe 1000 articles, so huge number, but really hard to navigate, just no way for you to make sense of them.
On the version, use the application or about to present.
Tries to deal with that so it tries to give you away for dealing with this large number of articles about a single topic about a single story or event.
It basically does everything with us, but on top of that it also provides you with some filtering and reordering tools.
These reordering tools allow you to.
Focus on.
Articles according to these 3 dimensions, first sentiment you might want to choose which is the positive or just the negative aspects of the story and then give focus to those those articles.
Second geography.
If, for example, something some bombing attack happens in Egypt, you can get the local news or you can get the US news and it makes a big difference.
The reports are going to be different probably, but there's no simple way for you currently.
To get that with existing existing platforms.
And unless the topic.
Let's say that Microsoft launches a new.
Software packager new product.

And again, you might be interested in the articles that right about the competitors, or you might be interested in the articles that right about the business implications or articles that write about.
Maybe the technical details of this new solution, so on top of re ranking we also offer in depth summary.
That gives you.
A summary of all those articles, but taking your focus, your priorities regarding these three attributes into account.
So if I want to focus on the US articles, I will get somebody.
Most of the US articles.
Now we back solve this into an application.
Two applications actually, one for the web and one for iOS and Jan will next present.
A live demo for the iOS solution.

Now this is live data from the server.

Published in.

I selected the geography and then I selected the sentiment.

1st.
Top level view.
So we have the articles on the web that we then Crow get into a local database that we process them and then we have the data in a structured form in our diverse new server.

So this part here is the actual application that we have the server client architecture and the client is very lightweight so most of the processing happens here on the server side and then we have the two clients.
the iPad that we just saw and the browser version.
Um?
I know I will follow.
This graph and just see how data changes through.
The pipeline.
First we have to start with the raw data.
We haven't mentioned this so far, but there has to come from somewhere, right?
Google News doesn't allow you to crawl it, so we have this product called News Feed that crawls RSS feeds, gets like 5000 thousand English articles per day.
Fairly quickly, so after the article is published, probably within three hours, we know about it and have it in our own database, but this was covered at last year's psyche release or not.
Go into details.
And once we have data, we have to clean it.
First, we have a heuristic that analyzes Dom tree, throws away everything but the clear text and then now with text we really can work.
The one remaining part of processing is to cluster these cleartext articles into stories.
This is Diana streaming fashion because the articles keep coming all the way.
I mean all the time we have.
An algorithm that keeps maintaining centroids of the last approximately 1 days worth of articles, and there's a new article comes, it just assigns it to the nearest centroid, the nearest cluster.
And there is an information criterion that decides when to split one large clusters.
And we do this periodically.
Alright, so now we have.
The data is clustered into stories and now we come to the actual user interface and how the back end supports it.
In the upper right corner, here in this section we have the topic navigation panel.
What this does is it takes all the articles.
Clusters them and then clusters into subtopics, hopefully right, and then for each subtopic it identifies the top features.
Of that cluster and displacement here.
And by moving the small and then once we've got these features so these clusters these clusters live in the high dimensional bag of word space.
Before displaying them, we use multidimensional scaling to project them into 2 dimensions and then display this which allows the user to actually navigate on the national screen among the topics.
Next up, we have the geography over here.
The interface hopefully is clear.
The art here is more in extracting the publisher information because there's no central way of knowing where the data comes from, so we're trying to aggregate several sources.
We crawled some web listings of publishers.
We Chrome RSS.
We tried to remain depend on the country code top level domain, so dealer Dot SC.
That means from Slovenia.
And also we have security things for calling who is.
And see what the.
Host name is that I just did.
And Lastly, we have the sentiment, which is that performs least well.
Just because newswire is subjective and it's objectively hard problem.
Um?
The way we do this is.

We tried several supervised methods and then in the end we have a bag of words based one that does first words, then it takes surface features like Smiley, switch in user is not present all that much but also punctuation and stuff.
These two are fed into a supervised model and then combined with lexical features like Santa Wordnet.
And this gave the best results.
The accuracy is, I think.
F1 is in the 70s, so it's.
Not that good, but also not hopeless.
And Lastly, we have the summary.
The summary was actually done by project partners by Google.
This was a result of a European project we had together, and the way the summary works is it's a sentence level expected summary, which means it ranks the sentences and pulls out some of them.
The way it does it is first looks at the whole cluster.
And the estimates the word frequencies, the distribution across the words and then tries to choose the sentences that will go into the summary in such a way that they will mimic this.
Distribution as closely as possible.
And the closeness of this mimicking is measured by the KL divergent.
Correct?
And that's it for the technical part.
This is the link to the web demo in case anybody wants to check it out.
It is.
I have to say less developed less.
For security, is the iPad one.
This was the first prototype actually and then we develop the iPad one.
But for any other questions you are here, thanks.
